title: TSX moves higher on U.S.-China trade optimism
text:
© Reuters. The Toronto Stock Exchange sing is seen in Toronto

(Reuters) - Canada's main stock index opened higher on Monday led by industrial stocks and tracking global equities, on signs of the United States and China making progress toward resolving their trade dispute.

* At 9:55 a.m. ET (13:55 GMT), the Toronto Stock Exchange's S&P/TSX composite index was up 42.64 points, or 0.26%, at 16,420.76.

* White House adviser Larry Kudlow said in an interview to Fox Business that tariffs scheduled for December could be withdrawn, if trade negotiations continue to go well sending global equities higher.

* Ten of the index's 11 major sectors were up, led by the industrials sector.

* The energy sector climbed 0.5% despite prices being down on the day. [O/R]

* The financials sector gained 0.4%, while the materials sector, which includes precious and base metals miners, added 0.3% even as remained unchanged at $1,488.4 an ounce.[GOL/]

* On the TSX, 135 issues were higher, while 88 issues declined for a 1.53-to-1 ratio favoring gainers, with 12.82 million shares traded.

* The largest percentage gainers on the TSX were Knight Therapeutics Inc (TO: ), which jumped 6.3% and Hudsons Bay Co (TO: ), which rose 5.9%.

* Hexo Corp (TO: ) fell 6.1%, the most on the TSX, while the second-biggest decliner was Aphria Inc (TO: ), which fell 2.1%.

* The most heavily traded shares by volume were Aurora Cannabis (TO: ), Green Orgnaic Dutchman Holdings (TO: ) and Encana Corp (TO: ).

* The TSX posted two new 52-week highs and three new lows.

* Across all Canadian issues there were 16 new 52-week highs and 11 new lows, with total volume of 25.57 million shares.
description: TSX moves higher on U.S.-China trade optimism
